review.title: Identifying the Absorption Bump with Deep Learning
review.abstract: The pervasive interstellar dust grains provide significant insights to help us understand the formation and evolution of the stars, planetary systems, and the galaxies, and could potentially lead us to the secret of the origin of life. One of the most effective way to analyze the dusts is via their interaction and interference on observable background light. The observed extinction curves and spectral features carry the information of the size and composition of dusts. Among the features, the broad 2175 Angstrom absorption bump is one of the most significant spectroscopic interstellar extinction feature. Traditionally, statistical methods are applied to detect the existence of absorption bump. These methods require heavy preprocessing and the co-existence of other reference features to alleviate the influence from the noises. In this paper, we apply deep learning techniques to detect the broad absorption bump. We demonstrate the key steps for training the selected models and their results. The success of deep learning based method inspires us to generalize a common methodology for the broader science discovery problems. We present our on-going work to build the DeepDis system for such kind of applications.

sections.heading: 2 TRADITIONAL METHOD FOR DISCOVERING ABSORPTION BUMP
sections.text: Previous research (Fitzpatrick & Massa (1990)) showed that the extinction curve and the variation in the intrinsic spectral inclination of a quasar can be represented by a parameterized linear component.A Drude component can be added to approximate the possible increase in absorbance.Overall, the representation of an extinction spectrum with an increase in absorption can be expressed as follows: A (λ) = c2 + c3D (x), where the spectrum is wavelength and x = 1. Component D (x0) is a Drude profile, and its definition is: D (x0) + c2 (x2) + x2 (2).

sections.heading: 3 IDENTIFYING THE ABSORPTION BUMP WITH DEEP LEARNING
sections.text: For the various disadvantages of the traditional method mentioned above, we propose a method based on deep learning that could alleviate these problems and offer more flexible application. In particular, the proposed method has the following advantages. • Large dataset enables accurate imaging learning. When generating the samples, we repeatedly have control over the selection of emission and absorption redshifts. After creating the model, no additional information is required for new observations. • Easy to use and transfer. With a trained model, any prediction on newly added observations is only a feed process. Practical models could also be easily shared between researchers. Beyond trained models, simulation parameters and simulated datasets are all user-friendly.

sections.heading: 3.1 RAW DATA GENERATION
sections.text: We have used two methods to generate the data set: The first method follows the corresponding part of the curve fit process. We refer to Berk et al. (2001) and obtain the SDSS data release 7 composite quasar spectrum as the intrinsic spectrum. Then, we modify the emission and absorption red shifts and add the absorption profile according to Equation 2. We select a typical bump profile: x0 = 4.59, γ = 1.0 and Abump = 2.0. To increase diversity and closely simulate the observations in the real world, we apply the second method. We have selected a subset of the spectra from the SDSS data release 7 according to the Mg II catalog from Zhu & Me'nard (2013). We follow the fit method described in Jiang et al. (2010a; 2011) and interweave it with the absorption bump profile indicating that we are as close to < these < to existing samples.

sections.heading: 3.2 CASE ONE: FULLY CONNECTED NEURAL NETWORK
sections.text: The first easy choice for the model is the fully connected neural network. Its effectiveness in capturing the nonlinearity relationships between the input characteristics has been tested in recent decades. To feed the training data into the fully connected neural network, we extracted the flux value as a vector and use this vector to train the model. We perform this data transformation based on the observation that the absorption surge is not related to the absolute wavelength value due to redshifts, but rather to the adjacent flux value relationship. Furthermore, the wavelength interval between two consecutive wavelength flux values is relatively stable in the data (both simulated and in the real world). Due to the data acquisition mechanism, the number of pairs in a sample may be slightly different. We added the samples with zeros to a total of 4761 flux values. The configuration of the fully connected neural network was changed and the number of neurons per signatory was covered.

sections.heading: 3.3 CASE TWO: IMAGE AND CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL NETWORK
sections.text: A quasar spectrum is represented as a black curve in Figure 1 when inspected by researchers, inspiring us to transform raw data into images. First, we record all training and test samples, with a wavelength coverage range of 8000 A, and about 50 for the flow. The raw image can be as large as hundreds of KB, scaled down to 256 * 256 grayscale images and used for training and testing. Recently, the Convolutionary Neural Network (CNN) (LeCun & Bengio (1995)) has proven its effectiveness in image-based recognition and classification due to its ability to divide parameters and capture localized patterns. We have adapted two popular CNN-based models, AlexNet (Krizhevsky et al. (2012)) and GoogLeNet (Szegedy et al. (2014)). The results we get for the modified AlexNet are 952% and 8.955% for GoogLegNet.

sections.heading: 3.4 CASE THREE: MATRIX AND CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL NETWORK
sections.text: The 256 * 256 image plus CNN model improves accuracy. However, the input image is too sparse given the large white background. In order to condense the input and strengthen the CNN model, we perform another data transformation. This transformation is also based on the assumption used for fully connected neural networks. Unlike the previous transformation, which is a 1D vector, we fill and fold the vector into a 69 * 69 matrix. This transformation allows filters in the volume layer to capture the localized information with adjacent flow values. We use different configurations of CNN and publish the best results we have in Table 2. We repair the CNN models with two fully connected layers after the volume layers and change the number of volume layers, the number of filters in each volume layer and the core size. The best model is achieved with two fully connected layers according to the volume layers and the number of each * 3.

sections.heading: 3.5 DISCUSSION
sections.text: In previous sections, we present three types of models and the corresponding data transformations. We select some of the trained models and draw their ROC curves shown in Figure 4, and the corresponding AUCs are given in Table 3. The ROC curves for the selected models are consistent with the previously reported test accuracy. For this absorption bump detection application, we could improve the sensitivity of the trained models by a slight reduction in the decision threshold. This could lead to slightly more false positive signals, but is more confident in detecting the potential absorption problems we are interested in.0.0 0.1 0.3 0.4false positive rate0.60.70.80.91.0tr u po siti v e ra tealexnet googlenet configurnet84.84.8different configurnet3 configured bump events we are interested in.0.0 0.2 0.4false positive rate0.60.91.0tr u po Figure 994.994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,84,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,84,84,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,994,84,84,80.3Table:

sections.heading: 4 GENERALIZATION: BOOSTING SCIENCE DISCOVERY WITH DEEP LEARNING
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 SCIENCE DISCOVERY PROBLEM
sections.text: Similar to the Absorption Bump Detection, a category of problems in other scientific fields involves the detection of a particular phenomenon among the background events. We call it the Science Discovery Problem. These discoveries are building blocks for further scientific research. Scientists rely on them to propose ideas, validate hypotheses and prove theories. A typical Scientific Discovery Problem consists of two main components, the feature set, F = {fi | 0 < i < N}, and the relationship between the characteristics, R. A Scientific Discovery Problem can be expressed as follows: D = {F | F х Rtarget (P, C), Rtarget, R} (3) D is the targeted discovery rate, P and C are parameters and constants. F is an event in F. Rtarget defines the relationships between the characteristics that represent the desired phenomenon. Rtarget and its complementary Set Rate, Rate, Rate, get, Rate, R.Rate, Rate, R., Rate, Rate, Rate, R.get, R., Rate, R.

sections.heading: 4.2 DEEP LEARNING BASED METHOD
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 5 CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this article, we introduced a deep-learning-based method for detecting the absorption disorder. We discussed in detail how we generated and transformed the training data according to the selected models. We presented the results for different models. To get a feeling for what the models learned, we chose the CNN-based AlexNet model and provided the visualizations of filters, function cards and reconstructed maximum activation input images. The resulting images prove that the model identifies the absorption disorder and not any other background noise. With the success in applying the deep-learning-based method for the absorption disorder, we generalized the Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-learning methodology to the broad scientific discovery problems, where deep-learning models can be effectively trained on sufficient amounts of data Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-Deep-Learning. We also showed our ongoing work in building a specialized system, DeepDis, to support the Deep Deep-Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep Deep De

referenceMentions.context: PAHs are recognized as the most abundant organic molecules in our Milk Way and other neighboring galaxies (Peeters et al. (2003)), and are believed to be the building blocks of organic life (Bernstein et al.
(2003)), and are believed to be the building blocks of organic life (Bernstein et al. (2002); Caro et al.
(2003)), and are believed to be the building blocks of organic life (Bernstein et al. (2002); Caro et al. (2002)).

(2003)), and are believed to be the building blocks of organic life (Bernstein et al. (2002); Caro et al. (2002)). The traditional way of discovering the absorption bump mainly depends on statistic techniques (Jiang et al. (2011)).

(2003)), and are believed to be the building blocks of organic life (Bernstein et al. (2002); Caro et al. (2002)). The traditional way of discovering the absorption bump mainly depends on statistic techniques (Jiang et al. (2011)). It generally involves three steps. First, a composite quasar spectrum is constructed using median combining (Jiang et al. (2010a;b)). The composite spectrum is then reddened and used to fit every spectrum from the candidate absorption bump spectra with a parameterized absorption profile. Finally, by applying constrains on peak position, bump width and bump height, a large portion of spectra without bump features are filtered out. In order to further exclude the false positives caused by some noises, a simulation technique (Jiang et al. (2010a;b)) is applied to determine the detection significance. Among the steps, curve fitting occupies considerable amount of time. In order to convolve the absorption bump with the composite spectrum, extra information is needed to determine the absorption redshift. This significantly constrains the available observations due to the lack of this extra information in some cases. While the composite quasar spectrum could potentially be reused for other related computations, the fitting procedure evolves iterative error minimization to get the best bump profile using curve fitting method, and is required for each and every new observation. The fitting is restricted to relatively smooth continuum of the quasar spectrum. However, the complicated types of emission and absorption in the candidate spectra could potentially disturb the fitting process, reducing the effectiveness of the method. All these issues are tightly coupled with the method itself, and cannot be easily resolved. In this paper, we propose to apply a Deep Learning based method to detect the absorption bump and try to alleviate the aforementioned issues. Deep Learning is recently recognized with its ability to automatically extract high level features and accurately recognize or classify the target objects (Hinton & Salakhutdinov (2006); LeCun et al.

(2003)), and are believed to be the building blocks of organic life (Bernstein et al. (2002); Caro et al. (2002)). The traditional way of discovering the absorption bump mainly depends on statistic techniques (Jiang et al. (2011)). It generally involves three steps. First, a composite quasar spectrum is constructed using median combining (Jiang et al. (2010a;b)). The composite spectrum is then reddened and used to fit every spectrum from the candidate absorption bump spectra with a parameterized absorption profile. Finally, by applying constrains on peak position, bump width and bump height, a large portion of spectra without bump features are filtered out. In order to further exclude the false positives caused by some noises, a simulation technique (Jiang et al. (2010a;b)) is applied to determine the detection significance. Among the steps, curve fitting occupies considerable amount of time. In order to convolve the absorption bump with the composite spectrum, extra information is needed to determine the absorption redshift. This significantly constrains the available observations due to the lack of this extra information in some cases. While the composite quasar spectrum could potentially be reused for other related computations, the fitting procedure evolves iterative error minimization to get the best bump profile using curve fitting method, and is required for each and every new observation. The fitting is restricted to relatively smooth continuum of the quasar spectrum. However, the complicated types of emission and absorption in the candidate spectra could potentially disturb the fitting process, reducing the effectiveness of the method. All these issues are tightly coupled with the method itself, and cannot be easily resolved. In this paper, we propose to apply a Deep Learning based method to detect the absorption bump and try to alleviate the aforementioned issues. Deep Learning is recently recognized with its ability to automatically extract high level features and accurately recognize or classify the target objects (Hinton & Salakhutdinov (2006); LeCun et al. (2015)).

We adapted two popular CNN based models, the AlexNet (Krizhevsky et al. (2012)) and the GoogLeNet (Szegedy et al. (2014)).
DeepDis integrates state-of-the-art distributed in-memory computing framework, Spark (Zaharia et al. (2012)), and the Caffe (Jia et al.
(2012)), and the Caffe (Jia et al. (2014)) Deep Learning toolbox to efficiently execute the data generation and model training tasks.

metadata.abstractText: The pervasive interstellar dust grains provide significant insights to understand the formation and evolution of the stars, planetary systems, and the galaxies, and may harbor the building blocks of life. One of the most effective way to analyze the dust is via their interaction with the light from background sources. The observed extinction curves and spectral features carry the size and composition information of dust. The broad absorption bump at 2175 Å is the most prominent feature in the extinction curves. Traditionally, statistical methods are applied to detect the existence of the absorption bump. These methods require heavy preprocessing and the co-existence of other reference features to alleviate the influence from the noises. In this paper, we apply Deep Learning techniques to detect the broad absorption bump. We demonstrate the key steps for training the selected models and their results. The success of Deep Learning based method inspires us to generalize a common methodology for broader science discovery problems. We present our on-going work to build the DeepDis system for such kind of applications.
